title: Meritocracy and Literature: Transcultural Approaches to Hegemonic Forms
descriptions:
The project "Meritocracy and Literature: Transcultural Approaches to Hegemonic Forms" (MERLIT) seeks to address the lack of comprehensive investigations into the formal principles of meritocratic narratives in literature. By exploring the practices of writing that shape meritocratic articulations and critiques, the project aims to offer a literary history of meritocratic thought from the 17th century to the present. 

One of the key objectives of MERLIT is to expand the contextual focus beyond Western contexts to include the Global South and transcultural anglophone contexts. By engaging with historical forms of meritocracy, the project seeks to advance our understanding of hegemonic forms in writing and highlight literature's worldmaking role. 

Utilizing a systematic, diachronic, and comparative approach, MERLIT will involve six work packages and draw on interdisciplinary fields such as literary history, new formalist theory, and cultural translation. Despite the criticisms of enmeshment with structures of domination and privilege, the project will provide a nuanced analysis of meritocratic narratives in literature with global relevance.

Overall, MERLIT represents a groundbreaking initiative that will contribute significantly to the field by bridging research gaps and offering new insights into the complex relationship between meritocracy and literature.
